@photonstorm Same problem plagues php, many db vendors, etc...
@photonstorm Yep. I saw that problem with shopping carts the day of a feature on Good Morning America. That was the day that sparked cuid.
@BrendanEich @PeteFromSeattle @Vintharas @raganwald TS and Flow are a start, but far from perfect. See also rtype/rfx. Not done, but cool.
@photonstorm Bottom line, if you're using pure random for unique id's, you're rolling dice with your user data. Ends in tears.
@photonstorm See https://t.co/VHejxEn0kZ
RT @photonstorm: @_ericelliott this one for sure: https://t.co/DwTiZkYbth
RT @BrendanEich: @_ericelliott @ShawnMcCool @codedungeon Reverse debugging is the future. https://t.co/tA8hdp9Cov
@javascriptjosh @BrendanEich Maybe, but can they run Unreal Engine + Unity in-browser at 60fps? ;)
@PeteFromSeattle @BrendanEich Looking forward to another cambrian explosion on top of wasm. First class wasm/js module import will rock.
@PeteFromSeattle @BrendanEich I'm all for language proliferation. Before the web, I used BASIC, ASM, Pascal, Delphi, AutoLisp, C/C++, Java..
@mattdesl @zeroload Who said anything about manual? https://t.co/3BQjqfm0aX
@philswenson @lcrespom I got out of the Java game before IntelliJ. Eclipse had deep issues. Desperately needed a rewrite last I used it.
@BrendanEich @ShawnMcCool @codedungeon I haven't seen rr-project before. Very cool! Could this eventually work with LLVM/wasm?
@ShawnMcCool @codedungeon @BrendanEich https://t.co/kxOGzy9x8O
@BrendanEich @ShawnMcCool @codedungeon these get blurry with runtime tools. See Redux time travel debugger.
@BrendanEich @PeteFromSeattle Our runtime tools make IDE auto complete look like a baby chew toy.
@BrendanEich @PeteFromSeattle & we more than make up for auto complete glitches with our totally unmatched runtime tools.
@BrendanEich @PeteFromSeattle @Cloud9IDE Also starting on runtime reflection with Reflect,  React.PropTypes, rfx: https://t.co/1H36JotzgD
@BrendanEich @PeteFromSeattle @Cloud9IDE We've had several decent type tools. JSDoc + Tern, definitely typed, flow type inference...
@ZombieCodeKill @r31gN_ @lcrespom There are many platforms at different levels of abstraction. And that's a good thing.
@ZombieCodeKill @r31gN_ @lcrespom You mean like the web platform, or Node, or the IoT platforms popping up? JS is many things.
@lcrespom This is why I switched. Getting my source maps to map wasn't intuitive w/browserify + several transform tools.
@lcrespom Don't say Java+Eclipse. It's horribly broken. :)
@lcrespom I've heard C# matches C++ experience, but can't personally vouch for it. Which others are rocking it?
@lcrespom C++ is the only other lang I've seen that comes close to JS dev experience, and only in the game engines. JS crushes others.
@lcrespom It has the best I've seen in a career spanning many languages.

As @BrendanEich says: Always bet on JS.
https://t.co/MFBbcO3Zzd
#JavaScript
@lcrespom Compare this boilerplate: https://t.co/dMIlc958rl
They said JS was slow. Now it's fast. Said we had no dev tools. We have the best. Said it sucks for big apps. We rock them. @BrendanEich
@lcrespom And other langs have compile steps, packaging, compression & post processing that makes runtime debug features almost impossible.
@lcrespom I don't lose my sourcemaps. Check your config. :)

@ljharb I prefer that when my repo says builds are passing, that should assure users that the code works. But it can't with mutable deps. );
@ljharb Could just be the freshness of the recent pain, but respectfully, strongly disagree.

The world where SemVer guarantees anything is a fantasy. It doesn't exist.
https://t.co/jDFNzOIoeU
https://t.co/3BQjqfm0aX
#npm #JavaScript
@ljharb And if the code is different, it's not a dupe. Again, this world where SemVer guarantees anything is a fantasy. Doesn't exist.
@ljharb There are tools for that. Tools that test automatically and automate PRs.
@ljharb Respectfully disagree after this latest round of scrambling to fix my libs that other people broke. Again.
@ljharb See https://t.co/3BQjqfm0aX
@ljharb They would if we could guarantee SemVer. Can you? Is that even possible?
@Steven__PA Yep. That's why we need collaboration and mentorship. Beginners shouldn't feel they're on their own.
@mattdesl @zeroload @revolunet What much larger problem is that?
@mattdesl @zeroload @revolunet But it is absolutely true that if we can't guarantee our deps, we can't guarantee that our software works. :|
@ljharb It's a systemic ecosystem problem that you as an individual rarely see, but taken in whole is a big problem.
@ljharb It happens to one individual person rarely. It happens very frequently is you consider the whole ecosystem.
@ljharb we're seeking an unscalable human solution when a technical solution is the only real fix available.
@ljharb The real problem is we're trusting people to not make mistakes when we could have immutable deps instead.
@ljharb Nope. Multiple. Blacklist is a poor solution to a widespread problem.
@ljharb There were multiple breaking sources I had to pin, and they're useful. Blacklist is a poor solution to a widespread problem.
@scripterson I agree with this, but also agree with both @raganwald's conflicting arguments. Paradox.
@Steven__PA practice teaches you how to deal with issues. You can't just absorb someone else's experience. You must experience for yourself.
@zeroload @mattdesl @revolunet so if Shrinkwrap is a solution only for top level apps, it's not a solution at all.
@zeroload @mattdesl @revolunet for libs, it's even more important that we help guard against breakage. Only way forward: immutable deps.
@zeroload @mattdesl @revolunet that "top level is responsible" line doesn't work if your broken libs break other libs, and so on...
@zeroload @mattdesl @revolunet The projects that broke while I was sleeping during Babel 6 transition were mostly libs.
@keithort @raganwald document your code in code, not comments. :) https://t.co/1H36JotzgD
@raganwald @scripterson Yep. See pros and cons of FP: https://t.co/aLGo68lgwe
Program readability is much more important than program writability. Be kind to your future self, and your team.
@mattdesl @revolunet @zeroload wrong. If you follow that advice, your projects will break while you sleep, eventually. Happened to me lots.
@mattdesl @revolunet @zeroload Yes, with an update to add https://t.co/3BQjqfm0aX to their projects.
@mattdesl @revolunet @zeroload https://t.co/3BQjqfm0aX
@zeroload @revolunet @mattdesl I'd rather cause a bit of duplication than break a bunch of people's downstream code completely.
@zeroload @revolunet @mattdesl Dream? Ideal? Pick the least offensive word for "it doesn't work like that in real life."
@ljharb @wbinnssmith I had to fix mine fast because they were causing other people build failures. I think I'll pin from now on.
@ljharb @wbinnssmith Somebody else updated something my libs depended on. My libs broke, which broke all the libs depending on them.
@ljharb @wbinnssmith My experience agrees with this: https://t.co/zyraKN7GvH
@revolunet @mattdesl @zeroload That's the fantasy. Here's the truth: https://t.co/zyraKN7GvH
@ljharb @wbinnssmith fixed by rolling back package versions until install + tests worked, then pinned versions for everything.
RT @kramp: @_ericelliott The cost of Frameworks  https://t.co/t5Vh0HusIK
@ljharb @wbinnssmith had to fix several repos that couldn't even npm install anymore. And eslint broke in my React projects.
@mattdesl Why not libs?
@wbinnssmith @ljharb Questioning my reasoning though after awkward Babel 6 ecosystem shakeup.
@wbinnssmith @ljharb That's what I thought.
@Manjeethakur Atom, Chrome, Redux, Redux dev tools, React + hot loader: https://t.co/dMIlc958rl
RT @ljharb: @_ericelliott pinning deps doesn't save you at all tho, because of subdeps. you should always use the ^, and shrinkwrap the top…
@ljharb Shrinkwrap libs? I never have, but maybe should.

Binary in JavaScript by @workshydev https://t.co/DrL1iz4hTa
#JavaScript
@cybwn What does auto complete tell you about exceptions? :)
@cmx66 Every JS dev, even if you do mostly FP, should understand delegation, obj concat and obj merge & related patterns and idioms.
@cmx66 delegation can be used to wrap ordinary maps, sets, pojos with chaining APIs for functors (see Array.prototype), etc...
@cmx66 If you restrict your understanding of OO to mutable state, you miss out on convenient stuff like chaining, data object concat & merge
@cmx66 sounds like we have different definitions of "prototypal OO". IMO, it is complementary to FP, and leads to more convenient fp.
@cybwn Types are highly overrated as an error catching mechanism. Underrated as documentation & a way to reduce cognitive load for devs.
@cybwn Throw indicators are still valuable though in that they indicate to developers that they should pay special attention to throw cases.
@cybwn I see what you mean. I think checked exceptions are an untenable problem. More trouble and overhead than it's worth.
@cmx66 yes it is. I specifically mention it in the list and even call special attention to it with an embedded video.
Every idea is a seed. It takes work and time to turn it into something valuable. Pick your best idea right now and get to work.
@cybwn In JS, only the async ones have given me error related headaches. You have a different experience?
@willaharian @George_harrap @lacker Something like this could make machine to machine transactions simple.
@willaharian @George_harrap @lacker It's the first iteration of what could become an inexpensive way to bake payments into hardware.
@SteveALee @code maybe soon. Let's see what the OSS community does with it. :)
@cybwn ah. You shouldn't throw from a typical async function. For Node callbacks, pass an Error object into the cb. Reject promises w/ Err.
